properties.media:imagetext:
The welcoming ceremony included the preparation and drinking of Yangona,
the native non-intoxicating drink. Quite & show. Then a spear dance by
the warriors folloud by singing which reminded me so much of the Hawailan
singing of 50 years ago. He spent the rest of the afternoon on the
beautiful beach in front of the Captaine "bure". Debby and I found song
fairly good shells.
The beach and harbor are surrounded by mountains
heavily wooded above a fringe of coconut palms which skirt the shore. The
meat of the coconut, or "Copra",
', is the only cash crop of the YasaMas. The
coconuts are gathered by the natives and carried by boat to a central drying
and shipping point.
Tuesday, Dec. 3. We sailed early, past a very high mountain with
See sit that area virgin tap do for eard hate or four undred
hundred years ago some invaders over-powered and killed all the warriors on
the island.
The wives and daughters having taken refuge on the mountaln
top leaped off the cliff. The natives have promised to bury Capt. Withers
on that mountain top. We cruised among the islands with a rod out most of
the time. We took turns fishing and I was lucky enough to catch a 35 1b.
yellow fin tuna, quite a battle. We stopped at a number of villages and
beaches including the "Blue Lagoon" a beautiful coral reef,- surrounded
lagoon with thousands of small highly colored fish swiming in and out of
the multi-colored coral in the crystal clear water.
Our final stop on our second day out was at Nacula island where
anchored at 6 p.m. At this place as the others we went ashore in a
snall dinghy usually in two bout loads.
After dinner on board the Captain
announced that the people of the island about thirty in all (excluding
children) had invited us to come ashore for Yangona and a "Mele" or
celebration.
They had built a big fire on the beach and in the light of
that fire they passed the Tangona - tastes like soapy water - when the
warrior in full war paint holds the coconut bowl straight out in front of
him you are supposed to clap your hands once, then hold out your bowl into
which he poures the Yangona.
You then must drink it all without stopping.
When your cup is dry you toss it on the ground and the natives chant in
Fijian "It 18 dry".
You then clap your hands three times and the ceremony,
so far as you are
concerned, is over. When we and our guests had all been
served, sitting on the ground, the natives started singing to the accomplament
of two or three ukes and one guitar. The singing is truly remarkable. In
the first place their language, as Hawalian, is composed of all vowels and
there is no harsh sound, then their voices and the music are both good and
finally they sing
the parts to perfection. Of course they just love any
to have a celebration.
In the early days the Missionarys taught
them that dancing was very wicked. Of course hymn singing was very good.
The natives loved
the hymns, that was ok - but they still wanted to dance
so the nissionarys compromised and let then dance the "Taralals" wherein
you stand side by side with your partner putting your arm around her and
she puts her arm around you.
Then you start to shuffle to the misie and
break away
when it stops.
The moon came out casting long shadows of the
tall coconut palms on the white beach with the water gently lapping the
